head.supplied: S. Brisbane ¶ Oct 3. 1872 ¶ Dear Sir ¶ ¶ Your list of Lindsaeas does not include L. media ¶ RBr [n d] rare in the north of the Colony, & it has no synonyms; do you refer it to L. teneta? ¶ ¶ I encl...

div.p: RB MSS M51, Library, Royal Botanic Gardens, Melbourne.

To proof. Check bot names.
MS found with a specimen of Lindsaea linearis (MEL 2150214). S. Brisbane
Qld.

Your list of Lindsaeas does not include L. media
inter before media deleted, possibly by M. the ink is much darker.
RBr [n d] rare in the north of the Colony, & it has no synonyms; do you refer it to L. teneta?

I enclose herewith fragments of two Lindseas; one is […] which Mr Baker I suppose, regards as the Australian equivalent of L. cultrata, & which must be [common …] in northern Queensland; the other is represented by a single frond in the national herbarium in the British Museum, and is there named L. linearis S[n]. & RBr. which it cannot be, though the specific name is very applicable to it; I have another Lindsaea here, which I will enclose if I can find an example agreeing much better with linearis, & is so named by Mr Baker, but differing in the tufted, not creeping rhizome, (though it really has no rhizome) [&c] uniformly green or strawcoloured stipites, thinner texture, and hetero genous fronds.

I have been carefully over Mr [Ben…s] Australian herbarium, & neither fern is to be found in it; what surprised me most however was with reference to our two Common Niphoboli, rupestris & confluens; the smaller delicate species, almost always found on shaded tree-trunks, with the most delicate filiform rachis, & which I had with others always supposed to be L. corflalus & which is not in Mr [G]. Smiths collection is there labelled Niph: rupestris, & I altered the name I had given my plant, […] Mr [B…'s] label & specimens before me; the coarse & larger Niphobolus as often found on rocks & boulders as upon trees, is there name N. confluens, though the same plant in Mr [G]. Smiths collection is named N. rupestris. I have not seen N. ad[her]cens near Brisbane. I shall be very glad of your Fragments,
does not look like 'Fragment
a
'.
which I would order if I could.

We are of course not strong in Alga here, the coral reefs offering too insecure a [nidus]; the aenemones Sp: are Cystophyllum muricatum, Saugnassum vulgare (?) Cauleopa sedoides Plocanicum or the allied genus Hymenocladia, Catenella & some [bloa] & Paphylas, food for the Dugong. I formerly paid a good deal of attention to European algae, & had much correspondence with the late Prof: Harvey.

Lindsaea lanuginosa, is a fine species & limited I presume to the north, as it is a New Guinea fern. L. microphylla is common about Brisbane, & L. […] plentiful in one [spot also]. L. patophylla or Eusifolia on Moreton island, small & stunted, a form intermediate between L. L. eusifolia & pentephylla.
I trust your official ? troubles are smoother: perhaps it would be better to consider a little the taste of the profamcar vulgus, omnipotent as they are in all our colonies.
